original_table_html:
Media advertising Consumer promotions
TV Samples
Radio Coupons
Newspaper Premiums
Magazines Refunds and rebates
Direct response advertising Contests and sweepstakes
Mail Bonus packs
Telephone Price-offs
Broadcast media Interactive
Print media Web sites
Computer-related E-mails
Media-related Banner ads
Place advertising Rich media ads
Billboards and posters Search
Movies, airlines, and lounges Videos
Product placement Message boards and forums
Point of purchase Chat rooms
Point-of-purchase advertising Blogs
Shelf talkers Facebook
Aisle markers Twitter
Shopping cart ads YouTube
In-store radio or TV Event marketing and sponsorship
Trade promotions Sports
Trade deals and buying allowances Arts
Point-of-purchase display allowances Entertainment
Push money Fairs and festivals
Contests and dealer incentives Cause-related
Training programs Mobile
Trade shows SMS & MMS messages
Cooperative advertising Ads
Location-based services
Publicity and public relations
Word-of-mouth
Personal selling
summary_markdown: This table outlines a hierarchical structure of marketing communications, broadly categorized into Media advertising, Consumer promotions, and Trade promotions. Media advertising encompasses traditional channels like TV, radio, newspapers, and magazines, alongside direct response methods (mail, telephone) and place advertising (billboards, point-of-purchase displays). Consumer promotions are further divided into direct incentives (samples, coupons, price-offs) and interactive digital strategies (websites, e-mails, social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter, and video content). Trade promotions target intermediaries with tools such as trade deals, allowances, push money, and training programs. The structure also highlights the growing importance of digital and interactive elements within consumer promotions, including mobile marketing and online advertising formats. Additionally, it acknowledges other key promotional tools like publicity, public relations, word-of-mouth, and personal selling.
